displayed_text: Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter) Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point.

Healthcare Professional: As of right now, yes. Doctor: Ok, I gotta do something about that. Doctor: So I can't believe so many people are willing to come in the week of Thanksgiving, but ok. Patient: Yeah. (pause) Healthcare Professional: Alright, so I'll make a copy of these and then when you're done treatment you can--or while they're ordering the drug, if you want to go over and make your appointments-- Patient: Go see Y__? Healthcare Professional: Yep, she just has to sign these first. So… Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: They won't take them without her signature. Doctor: I’m just a - I’m just wondering, how long did we wait? We waited two weeks now? Healthcare Professional: It was two weeks from-- Doctor: Two weeks from his last uh, when he was last due?

Patient: Mmm.hmmm. Doctor: Does that hurt? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay, how far can you bring it? (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: No? How about the other side? (Pause) Patient: That’s fine. Doctor: No pain? Patient: I don’t even get the pain when I’m sitting around the house. Doctor: Really? Patient: When I go to sleep at night… Doctor: Okay, maybe it’s not that bad. Okay, push down on mine. Push, push, push. Patient: Push, just push

Patient: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s perfect timing then. I’ll see you around the middle to the second half of January and we’ll check your PSA and your testosterone level at that point, about a week or two before. And I’ll give you a paper printout as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And hopefully the PSA will still be quite low at that point so we won’t have to take any action. You guys have any other questions you want to ask while we’re getting this done? Patient: No, No, the Lupron, yeah, yeah. Doctor: Perfect. Glad you’re continuing to do well. Again you look pretty well. Patient: Yeah. I feel great. It’s just the energy. Doctor: Yes. (keyboarding sounds) Patient: Wednesdays are fine. Doctor: That works better for you. Patient: Yes. But I’ll tell you it doesn’t matter. Whatever your schedule dictates. It doesn’t really matter. Doctor: Wednesday should be perfect.

Patient: Yeah, I know that. Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: So. Um. You know, my sense is that it is research because we’ve got a new drug added to it. You know, looking forward to having the conversation about what options might be still important. Um. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um. Um. (Pause5sec) Patient: So, why don’t we try to, to, to have the blood taken and, and, see if, if what that brings back, but maybe a a - in lieu of that possibly being negative, um, look at the other clinical trial. Doctor: So, I’ll go print out, uh, do you want me to just not print out the chemo one? Patient: Yeah. Yeah, I guess. Doctor: So, I’ll print out the phase one and I’ll print out the immune therapy one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, those are two sort of, uh, things that you can be taking home and reading. Patient: Right. Doctor: I would stay with the current treatment for now.

Family Member 2: So you don’t have any more questions K___? Family Member: I don’t think so. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah I know, she said that. Family Member 2: We’re glad that she was able to come. Doctor: Yeah, no that’s wonderful. Yeah it’s important to… What do you think or are you ready to bail from this treatment? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You are. Okay. No that’s critical information that I need to know (laughs) Family Member 2: He doesn’t like the trips. Doctor: I know, know. Patient: Yeah, that’s the thing. Family Member 2: It’s, it’s, it’s, it’s you know, now it’s only like every three weeks so… Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad.

Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Sound good? Patient: Thank you again. Doctor: Tell them before the end of July because I’m taking off June and July I’m having hip surgery. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So I’ll be seeing you though towards the end of July. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Did you want to see him before we go? Healthcare Professional: Yes I do.

Patient: Yeah. That works for me. Doctor: Yeah. Blood work, Aximun scan. You're not on MyChart? Patient: I tried to get on MyChart, but the little number that he sent me, died or whatever. Doctor: Yeah, but I can we can print out a new one for you today. Patient: Okay good. Doctor: And then if you can just MyChart message me your email- Patient: Yes. Doctor: -but as to you know, my Aximun scan is scheduled for this day. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then I can add you in for the following Tuesday. Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Without knowing when that schedule, there's probably not anybody there. So we'll see what that looks like.

Patient: Right. Doctor: We just need a plan and know where we are. So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But, your earlier ones prior to July were sort of January/February time point. So, if I just take down the bone, you’ve had a variety of different reports, right so your January one was lots of different spots and then I think your July one we don’t have an official report but it didn’t seem to change much, you know, kind of different spots, but then on the CAT scan it only just showed one area because it was such a limited area that I would imagine that your bones still have multiple spots. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We know that your PSA hovers around the one twenty nine, one thirty mark. It’s kind of been staying there. It’s not five hundred but it’s not fifty, Patient: Right. Doctor: but it’s enough to say this might be the reason why, you know, you’re getting more tired and having some pain which may not be related to that. Now, your actual CAT scan reports are always a little inconsistent so that’s why I think it’s not confusing but challenging.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation? Doctor: So we actually prefer it because we actually know how to treat your whole body systemically with all these medicines from the chemist. (whistle noise) Patient: Right. Doctor: With these medicines, but we also, and it also gives you more time to heal. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: From the surgery, which is better for you as far as long-term side effects. Family Member: Uh hum. Okay.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And so half the people get it, half the people don’t- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but you still have to come in and get an infusion three times a week. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so that one is logistically pretty tough. But that is something that you know if we’re going chemotherapy, I can make sure we get you the permission slip or the consent form to let you know what that would look like. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may, I don’t think we have an opening at Hospital B but that’s one of the sites that we collaborate with, and I think they had interest in opening it, and so we can check in to see whether they have that open. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But that would be clearly if we say I’m doing chemotherapy, do I want to do something more on top of it, so that would be one option. Experimentally we have two treatments, uh one based on the fact that your ARV7 is positive. We have an experimental study where we give everyone immune therapy, a doublet. That is a combination of two drugs that are approved in melanoma, soon to be approved in kidney cancer that can turn on your immune system to attack your cancer. It doesn’t work all that well so far in prostate cancer, maybe fifteen percent of people may get a benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: That’s where the cohorts come up to six. Patient: Come up to six. Okay. So, so, it can - alright. Doctor: I’m willing to accept one out of three people having trouble. Um. And so, if we see one out of three, we don’t know whether it is actually more, so we add six. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, if two out of six get into trouble, then we stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if only one out of six, then we keep going. Patient: Alright. So, if I were to join this and they kinda get shut down, I can’t go back to what I’m doing right now then. Doctor: We can use Enzalutamide, Patient: Okay. Doctor: -but you can’t use the TGF-A drug Patient: Okay. And we don’t know what is, uh, is keeping the PSA level at ten. It, it, it’s, it’s not going -

Family Member: We’re being nice to them and saying here, look at this. & DOC Laughing]] Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay so first of all let me go ask Dr. L____ if he can see you today. Patient: Okay, oh yeah? That would be nice. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Let me go check with him. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And meanwhile as I get all the scans and all that and get a chance to look at your bone scans. Patient: Do you want me to step out or stay here? Doctor: Uh stay here. If Dr. L____ wants you moved to a different room of his I’ll let you know. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: Sounds good. Thank you. Doctor: Okay and today your Lupron and all that you’ve been getting right with Dr. K____. Okay so that’s updated.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.10 or more times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::10 or more times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay and uh then we’ll plan for your appointment after the cryo and everything is done. So forget about the June appointment. We’ll just schedule something later on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because probably the whole month of June will be taken up so most likely it will be somewhere end of July or so. Okay? Patient: So how do I make the appointment for the scope? Doctor: Yeah I’m gonna tell them so the scheduler will hook you up or J the nurse will talk to the scheduler. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll either know today or they may have to call you once they put you on the schedule. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: And then how long after that scope thing? Doctor: Usually then he’ll pick a date so. Family Member: Oh okay.
